Introducing a clause which is the subject or object of a verb (such as one involving reported speech), or which is a complement to a previous statement.
examples: He told me that the book is a good read.
I believe that it is true. — She is convinced that he is British.

senses.sense: Introducing a subordinate clause expressing a reason or cause: because, in that.
examples: Be glad that you have enough to eat.

senses.sense: (dated) Introducing a subordinate clause that expresses an aim, purpose, or goal ("final"), and usually contains the auxiliaries may, might, or should: so, so that.
examples: He fought that others might have peace.

senses.sense: Introducing — especially, but not exclusively, with an antecedent like so or such — a subordinate clause expressing a result, consequence, or effect.
examples: The noise was so loud that she woke up.
The problem was sufficiently important that it had to be addressed.

senses.sense: (archaic or poetic) Introducing a premise or supposition for consideration: seeing as; inasmuch as; given that; as would appear from the fact that.
Introducing a subordinate clause modifying an adverb.
examples: Was John there? — Not that I saw.
How often did she visit him? — Twice that I saw.

senses.sense: (archaic or poetic) Introducing an exclamation expressing a desire or wish.
examples: Oh that spring would come!

senses.sense: Introducing an exclamation expressing a strong emotion such as sadness or surprise.
The (thing, person, idea, etc) indicated or understood from context, especially if more remote physically, temporally or mentally than one designated as "this", or if expressing distinction.
examples: That book is a good read. This one isn't.

That cat of yours is evil.

senses.sense: (demonstrative) The thing, person, idea, quality, event, action, or time indicated or understood from context, especially if more remote geographically, temporally or mentally than one designated as "this", or if expressing distinction.
examples: That's my car over there.

senses.sense: The known (thing); used to refer to something just said.
examples: They're getting divorced. What do you think about that?

senses.sense: (demonstrative) The aforementioned quality or proposition; used to emphatically affirm or deny a previous statement or question.
examples: The water is so cold! — That it is.
Would you like another piece of cake? — That I would!

senses.sense: (relative) (plural that) Which, who; representing a subject, direct object, indirect object, or object of a preposition.

senses.sense: (colloquial) Used in place of relative adverbs such as where or when; often omitted.

Definite grammatical article that implies necessarily that an entity it hints at is presupposed; something already mentioned, or completely specified later in that same sentence, or assumed already completely specified.
examples: I’m reading the book. (Compare I’m reading a book.)
The street in front of your house. (Compare A street in Paris.)
The men and women watched the man give the birdseed to the bird.

senses.sense: Used before a noun modified by a restrictive relative clause, indicating that the noun refers to a single referent defined by the relative clause.
examples: The street that runs through my hometown.

senses.sense: Used before an object considered to be unique, or of which there is only one at a time.
examples: No one knows how many galaxies there are in the universe.
God save the Queen!

senses.sense: Used before a superlative or an ordinal number modifying a noun, to indicate that the noun refers to a single item.
examples: That was the best apple pie ever.

senses.sense: Added to a superlative or an ordinal number to make it into a substantive.
examples: That apple pie was the best.

senses.sense: Introducing a singular term to be taken generically: preceding a name of something standing for a whole class.
Used before an adjective, indicating all things (especially persons) described by that adjective.
examples: Feed the hungry, clothe the naked, comfort the afflicted, and afflict the comfortable.

senses.sense: Used to indicate a certain example of (a noun) which is usually of most concern or most common or familiar.
examples: No one in the whole country had seen it before.
I don't think I'll get to it until the morning.

senses.sense: Used before a body part (especially of someone previously mentioned), as an alternative to a possessive pronoun.
examples: A stone hit him on the head. (= “A stone hit him on his head.”)

senses.sense: When stressed, indicates that it describes an object which is considered to be best or exclusively worthy of attention.
examples: That is the hospital to go to for heart surgery.

senses.sense: With a comparative or with more and a verb phrase, establishes a correlation with one or more other such comparatives.
examples: The hotter the better. (comma usually omitted in such very short expressions)
The more I think about it, the weaker it looks.
The more money donated, the more books purchased, and the more happy children.
It looks weaker and weaker, the more I think about it.

senses.sense: With a comparative, and often with for it, indicates a result more like said comparative. This can be negated with none.
examples: It was a difficult time, but I’m the wiser for it.
It was a difficult time, and I’m {none - not any} the wiser for it.
I'm much the wiser for having had a difficult time like that.
